title: Which presidential candidate will win Pennsylvania?
preds: *This is definitely cheating - would work only in case GJO makes a mistake to include today in the scores (as indicated by resolution date)*
Live NYT results coming in giving Trump 63% odds of winning

Clinton has spent more time in Philly and her surrogates in PA lately.  Also, I had put the odds for Trump higher because there was a public transit strike going on in Philly, but that ended today.  New numbers are similar to Nate Silver's guess (though I found that out after I put in my guess).

538 is not giving Hillary a 77% prob. to win that state. Hillary had a big campaign rally there tonight while Trump was in New Hampshire:  
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/pennsylvania/
Based on polls and historical electoral data, I show Clinton with between 51% and 66% of the votes that will matter on election night

11/7: Most recent polls looked at indicate Hillary maintaining a lead... http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/pennsylvania/ http://www.cnn.com/2016/11/07/politics/presidential-polls-new-hampshire-pennsylvania/index.html http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/us/elections/polls.html http://www.270towin.com/2016-polls-clinton-trump/pennsylvania/ http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/pollster/2016-pennsylvania-president-trump-vs-clinton
Hillary has put this state as a firewall. Finally campaign rally philadelphia tonight.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

Latest Quinnipiac poll has Clinton leading by 5 pts. 
Hillary's organizational advantage is giving her the edge.
A Democrat-leaning swing state. Polls suggest a closeish race, though definitely Clinton looks in a good place.
Polls stabilizing, with Clinton's star-studded finale blunting Trump's comeback. Clinton should have Pennsylvania in the bag.
Though margin has tightened clinton has clear lead and Democrat's money  and GOTV edge heavily focused on ensuring state.

11/5/16: Some 'tightening' observed in recent PA election poll results. Clinton still narrowly ahead: http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/pennsylvania/ http://www.270towin.com/2016-polls-clinton-trump/pennsylvania/ http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/pa/pennsylvania_trump_vs_clinton_vs_johnson_vs_stein-5964.html

Average of 12 Polls
Last Poll: Nov. 4
CLINTON 48%
Trump 43%
Unlikely to flip beyond DT's closing to make in lean rather than safe for HC.
The transit union strike may affect Philadelphia which leans Democract with Western-side of Pennsylvania leaning towards the Republican candidate.
Clinton's lead has dwindled from a few weeks ago but appears to be holding.

Trump has been gaining in the polls and is on a pretty good streak of not drawing negative attention to himself, while meanwhile Clinton continues to face new negative news including the whole FBI email thing.

11/4: If polls (etc.) are to be believed, Hillary appears to still be generally 'hanging tough' in PA. ..Though it may be close. Sources considered:
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/pennsylvania/ http://www.270towin.com/2016-polls-clinton-trump/pennsylvania/ http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/pa/pennsylvania_trump_vs_clinton_vs_johnson_vs_stein-5964.html http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/us/elections/polls.html?

Hillary has been up in all polls since the end of October in Pennsylvania, and Nate Silver is around 75% for Hillary right now.  But Melania just gave a speech in PA that was well received (kinda), and there's also a SEPTA strike in Philly that may lower voter turnout.  I'm giving Hillary a lower chance than Nate Silver because of this.
Polls closing, huge effort by trump in PA. He can't win without PA. Right demographics. Trump will likely outperform polls by a few points. So I'd put this at 50/50.

Expecting Pennsylvania's ~53% ACA premium increase (http://www.thefiscaltimes.com/2016/11/01/Here-s-How-Much-Obamacare-Premiums-Are-Rising-All-50-States) to shock some voters back toward Trump, + general race tightening cycle through mid-end of week.

11/2: Still unable to find convincing evidence of Trump overcoming his opponent's apparent lead in this state.  Main sources considered: http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/pennsylvania/ http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/pa/pennsylvania_trump_vs_clinton-5633.html http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/10/27/upshot/pennsylvania-poll.html? http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/which-tipping-point-states-favor-trump/ http://heavy.com/news/2016/11/clinton-vs-trump-presidential-polls-2016-latest-new-battleground-states-who-is-leading-hillary-florida-ohio-pennsylvania-national-nevada-texas-arizona-georgia-colorado-utah-north-carolina-new-hampshir/

I live in Pa and I've met many Democrats who have confided that they are voting for Trump.
It is going to depend on Philadelphia and the voter turnout there. If it rains on election day, Trump takes PA.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

Average of 5 polls as of 10/30/2016:
CLINTON 47%
Trump 42%

Latest polls:
10/24/2016 Remington research: CLINTON 45%, Trump 42%
10/27/2016 NYT Upshot/Siena college: CLINTON 49%, Trump 42%
10/28/2016 Emerson college: CLINTON 48%, Trump 43%

Basing on this: http://www.realclearpolitics.com/docs/2016/Remington_PA_Oct_25th_2016.pdf In Pennsylvania's media markets, Trump is leading convincingly, except in Philadelphia, which no one expected him to carry. Even in Pittsburgh, which Obama won handily, Trump is effectively tied with Clinton. I think Trump will outperform Romney in Pennsylvania, and I think Clinton will underperform Obama's 2012 figures. Moreover, I think many white voters who stayed home in 2012 will vote this year. Of course, this is based on media markets not counties, but it conforms to what I had suspected for a long time (confirmation bias!), that Trump would carry the rural areas and smaller cities by a wide margin. I think he'll also be competitive in Bucks County, which Obama carried, but not by much.

Real Clear Politics declared Pennsylvania a "toss up" Confusing because polls on their site still favor Clinton.  Clinton's campaign is putting a lot of money and effort into that state.  Huge GOTV operation going on there now.  I will up Trump slightly but will keep Clinton over 80% until more polls come out. http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/2016_elections_electoral_college_map.html

Apparent "last-minute" negative for Hillary (ref. sources below); not yet clear to what extent though. (In PA and elsewhere.)  
Slight forecast adjustment for now.. http://www.cbsnews.com/news/fbi-is-taking-investigative-steps-to-review-more-clinton-emails/ http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/29/us/politics/fbi-hillary-clinton-email.html http://www.marketwatch.com/story/3-ways-a-fresh-fbi-probe-into-clinton-emails-hit-wall-street-2016-10-28?
Adjusting for FBI investigation.  Still very likely, but much less certain than yesterday.
Poll average since 2015 adjusted for probability of leading. Ignores third party candidates. 44 polls included.
I think Trump has a better chance here than he appears to.
I am extremizing this as the consensus seems pretty clear at such a late stage.

Swinging for a home run now.

10/20/16: Doubtful Donald Trump significantly reversed current trends (ref. various polls) via last night's debate. Time may be running out. Hillary campaign reportedly ramping up spending in swing states, incl. PA (second source below). Hillary reportedly running strong in Philly suburbs (third source) Sources considered: http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/clinton-probably-finished-off-trump-last-night/ http://www.pbs.org/newshour/updates/clinton-ramps-spending-swing-states-final-campaign-stretch/ http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-10-13/pennsylvania-poll http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/pennsylvania/

Penn always votes Dem
Philly and suburbs will have big turnout against Trump

Most recent polls: http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/pa/pennsylvania_trump_vs_clinton-5633.html
Hillary has raised five times more money in Pennsylvania than Trump.  Trump's campaign says that they have 12 offices in the state but press have reported all but one may be close.  Clinton, in contrast, has 55 offices open in that state. The advantage is clear.
Some people will attribute this to massive fraud.  Others will attribute it to massive legitimate use of the franchise.  Doesn't matter who's right--she wins Pennsylvania.

10/17/16: Most polls continue to indicate a Hillary lead in PA. ...Trump already sounding like a sore loser. 
Watching for "last-minute surprises", both campaigns. Sources considered: http://www.cnn.com/2016/10/17/politics/virginia-presidential-poll-christopher-newport-university/ http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/pa/pennsylvania_trump_vs_clinton-5633.html http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/pennsylvania/ http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/pollster/2016-pennsylvania-president-trump-vs-clinton

Upping Clinton based on latest poll results
http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/upshot/pennsylvania-election-forecast.html More from Politico
http://www.politico.com/blogs/swing-states-2016-election/2016/10/clinton-trump-polls-colorado-florida-pennsylvania-ohio-who-is-winning-229898 Instead of trying to crack Pittsburgh,  maybe Ohio and Florida present better opportunities for Trump.  On the other hand, I think Trump's demographics would probably have more turnout come election time and the fact that he is still trying to get PA means all hopes are not lost.  The positive forecasts for Clinton may be a curse instead of a blessing due to supporter complacency and not showing up to vote.
It seems to be in the bag, so to speak.

Clinton held a 9-point lead in Pennsylvania, according to a new Bloomberg Politics poll released Thursday. Most striking was her lead in the Philadelphia suburbs -- the place where many strategists believe this race will be won or lost. A startling 56% of suburban Philadelphia voters said they were supporting Clinton, compared to 28% for Trump. (CNN.com)

10/13/16: Current guess is that a majority of U.S. voters will choose not to elect "'Sideshow Bob'/'Krusty the Clown' Donald" as their next president.. ..Continuing to watch for (further) "October surprises" etc., both campaigns. 538 gives an 84.3% chance of Clinton win. Taking that as a baseline and adjusting upward, since polls would not yet factor in Friday's news. I also think 538's estimate is a bit too conservative (in the statistical sense of the word, not political).

Pennsylvania should be an easy win for Clinton, especially since Barbara Bush, said she liked Bill Clinton and couldn't believe any woman would vote for, Trump. Pennsylvania has nearly 5% more women than men. Barbara Bush's words still carry a lot of weight, especially with women, who see her as a loving and strong grandmother type. Every woman looks up to her grandmother.
PredictWise prediction market & polling data analysis.

+ 2 From 54 HC '“The Philadelphia Democrats have a political machine,” he said. “There virtually isn’t a Republican Party in Philadelphia.”
://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/07/2016-donald-trump-philadelphia-black-african-american-delegate-pennsylvania-214109?cmpid=sf
This could possibly be closer than 2004 dependent on the voter registration and turnout of the white non college educated demographic.

After seeing the market positioning of the two campaigns in their conventions, I think the Dems have the edge in getting swing states, and keeping marginally Dem states. The biggest risk to the forecast would be some current event that reinforces a darker world-view.

In the past 5 elections, the Democratic candidate has, in Pennsylvania, outperformed the national average by ~1-2% - based on the current polling average (and the accompanying margin of error), this would lead to a distribution skewed towards Clinton (but not insurmountably so for Trump, especially given his non-traditional electoral coalition)

Pennsylvania is a battle of Dem cities vs GOP rural areas with the suburbs deciding. Rural areas have seen payments for fracking wells drop as the price of oil dropped, Frack wells are associated with health problems and if a fracking company goes bankrupt then the state gets stuck with the clean up bill.  Who do you think voters want in charge of government to clean frack wells before they pollute the local water table and make their neighbor's land polluted? Many Suburbs must keep growing or die because their population density/tax revenue can't sustain their infrastructure ( example sewer lines a 1/4 of a mile in a city can easily service 10,000 in a suburb 2,000 may have to pay taxes for upkeep and replacement) you can't expand if the local farmland's water is polluted. Suburbs must grow and pass cost of replacement and maintence onto new residents.
Very in-depth article offers some pretty convincing analysis: http://www.nationalreview.com/article/438269/donald-trump-pennsylvania-path-white-house
Pennsylvania has been a solid blue state for quite a while and I do not see that changing. Being next to New York and the home of VP Biden are significant factors in it staying Democratic on balance.

DEMOCRATIC PRIMARY: Hillary got 55.6% or 918,689 votes
REPUBLICAN PRIMARY: Trump got 56.7% or 892,702 votes  Latest polls have Hillary leading by 2-4% http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/pa/pennsylvania_trump_vs_clinton-5633.html But we have to keep a close eye on this:
"Swing-state stunner: Trump has edge in key states" Politico, July 13, 2016 Read more: http://www.politico.com/blogs/swing-states-2016-election/2016/07/trump-has-edge-in-key-states-225442#ixzz4FRapeTMi  The article cites a poll by Quinnipiac University which shows Trump leading Clinton in Florida and Pennsylvania and "tied in the critical battleground state of Ohio."   "In three of the states that matter most in November, the surveys point to a race much closer than the national polls, which have Clinton pegged to a significant, mid-single-digit advantage over Trump, suggest." "The race is so close that it's within the margin of error in each of the three states. Trump leads by three points in Florida — the closest state in the 2012 election — 42 percent to 39 percent. In Ohio, the race is tied, 41 percent to 41 percent. And in Pennsylvania — which hasn't voted for a Republican presidential nominee since 1988 — Trump leads, 43 percent to 41 percent.
https://ballotpedia.org/Presidential_election_in_Pennsylvania,_2016 poll between the two indicates hillary is winning
Rural PA appeal for Trump; Fracking is helping the PA economy

«And in Pennsylvania, it's Clinton 43 percent, Trump 35 percent, Johnson 8 percent and Stein 2 percent.» ://www.nbcnews.com/politics/first-read/polls-clinton-ahead-or-even-midwest-battlegrounds-n608651

Secretary Clinton will continue to lock down the base of the party and will pick up suburban Republican women which will off set losses to Western PA Democrats.

Virtue, liberty, and independence
Pennsylvania has the 10th highest tax burden in the United States
Since 1992, Pennsylvania has been trending Democratic in Presidential elections, voting for Bill Clinton twice by large margins (Bill Clinton will work with economic questions)
Trump won all but one county in the primaries.

While Pennsylvania has been trending towards Republicans and has a large population of economically distressed white men, it has still been consistently Democratic to this point, and Clinton has still held a lead in early polling.
Very liberal eastern part of the state will swing vote to Clinton.

I think past voting and current demographics put Pa in the Dem column. The recent Q'piac poll that had Trump up might give some slight pause for thought, but it's just one sample and we're a long way out from November, so I'm going to regard that as more noise than signal for now. Unless HRC starts to collapse, I'd see it as a relative long shot for Trump to win Pennsylvania.
Has gone democrat every year since 1992. One poll does have Trump up 2%, but it's just one poll for now so I'm not going to overreact.
According to general news, gjp. and 538.com.
Going with 538 polls-plus -- a tiny bit more conservative than their polls-only in PA.

OK, read up a bit on PA. A lot more registered D:  D ~ R+Other. OTOH, 2016 has appreciably higher number than in previous years of D switching to R and D switching to O: 
http://www.dos.pa.gov/_layouts/download.aspx?SourceUrl=http://www.dos.pa.gov/VotingElections/OtherServicesEvents/VotingElectionStatistics/Documents/currentvotestats.xls So, an edge to D but far from a slam dunk. And it's pretty close in polls.
Trump will pull in Anti establishment, protectionist, 2nd amendment voters who will be more motivated to vote than anyone other than older women and african americans.
Being next to New York and Joe Biden's home state, it will go heavily Democratic. Also, being close to New York, the voters are also familiar with Donald Trump.
I expect Republican voter turnout to be lower than expected. These voters wont vote for hillary but will decide not to vote for trump either.
All I know is that it's going to be close. So my [winning] strategy is to simply go 50/50 on all election questions that have consensus at better than 2/1 for Clinton.
Trump will be gone by November.

Based on history, Democrats do have an edge but not overwhelming. So, I start with 55%.  2008 to 2012 saw a drop in the support for Dems - lower odds to 53% Recent events in Paris will fuel anti-islam, anti-immigration fever helping Trump. Odds for Hillary reduced to 52%. Need to watch this development closely.  This election will be less about economy and more about islam and immigration.

Slight edge to Clinton based on the national polls. Using the state polls, it may be better to evaluate changes in forecasts, due to differences in polling methodologies. Battle of the polls. Trump looks better in Quinnipiac polls. Clinton better in others. 
Some media reports criticize Quinn's breakout of voter group percentages to under represent minorities.

I live in central PA, and I expect Trump to do very well in most of the state. Clinton will easily win the major metropolitan areas, and the key regions will be the suburbs that have flipped in past elections. I'm more bullish on Trump in those areas than some statistical models seem to be (e.g. http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/pennsylvania/)

Trump will carry white working class precincts in the big cities, the white vote in the smaller cities, and all of rural Pennsylvania. The northeastern counties that Obama carried in 2012 will break for Trump this year.
